body: The file import feature is not good. I should design it again.
Hey have you got around to fixing this issue? I also can't import ConLL formatted files.

issue.title: Known issue about Annotation UI

repository.name: doccano
repository.description: Open source annotation tool for machine learning practitioners.

issue.body:
**Please read this issue when you faced the problem of annotation user interface.**  
**If you faced the following issue, please upvote 👍 related issue that let us judge priority.**

* Display
  * [x] Nonworking delete button is shown for labels of other users #866
  * [x] Feature Request: Keep and Display the new line in the Text Classification Task #879
  * [x] RTL language Support #769
  * [x] Can't change from "Checked" to "Not Checked"? #481
* Filter
  * [x] Done / Undone filter does not work correctly #808
  * [x] After filtering the dataset when clicking the annotation it is not shown the proper data (from the filter) #765
  * [x] Choosing filter twice results in 404 error #754
  * [x] The display of the document index does not change after filtering #594
* Pagination
  - [x] Pagination unresponsive for large documents #873 
  - [x] Execute refresh above the pagination-boundary example causes miss ordering #804 
* File upload
  - [x] Make upload file constraints more clearly #521
  - [x] [Enhancement request] Allow to import unlabeled datasets #658
  - [x]  Unable to import CoNLL files #1046

body:
@jonathan-goh Thank you for using doccano and your appreciation is vital for us.
We pick this issue at #880 and tackle to solve this.

I figured out a solution for this. First you need to convert your ConLL format into a list of lists format, such as:

`sentences[0:2]`
output:
```
[['EU', 'rejects', 'German', 'call', 'to', 'boycott', 'British', 'lamb', '.'],
 ['Peter', 'Blackburn']]
```
`labels[0:2]`
output:
```
[['B-ORG', 'O', 'B-MISC', 'O', 'O', 'O', 'B-MISC', 'O', 'O'],
 ['B-PER', 'I-PER']]
```

Then with the code below:


```
import pandas as pd
# exploding the list of lists into a flat list and then determining what are the unique values py using pandas
unique_labels = pd.Series(list(chain.from_iterable(labels))).unique()
unique_labels = list(unique_labels)
# we need to remove the "O" label
unique_labels.remove("O")

# create an empty list to create a list of dictionaries
list_json = []

for x, i in enumerate(sentences):
    list_json.append({"id": x}) # create id key for sentence
    list_json[x]["text"] = " ".join(i) # create the text key for the sentence
    list_json[x]["labels"] = [] # create an empty label key to later append
    for y, j in enumerate(labels[x]):
        if j in unique_labels:
            word = i[y] # determine what the word is
            # 
            # If I don't add an if statement here, the label indexes for the first always got tagged 1 index to the right
            # I am not sure why but this if statement fixes the problem
            #
            if y == 0: 
                # determining the start and end index of the label in the sentence
                wordStartIndex1 = len(" ".join(i[0:y])) # join word elements with a space until the word index to determine the start of the label index
                wordEndIndex1 = len(" ".join(i[0:y]))+ len(word) # add the length of the word to determine the End index
                list_json[x]["labels"].append([wordStartIndex1, wordEndIndex1, j])
            # same thing but if its not the first of the sentence, we add 1 to the start and end indexes
            else:
                wordStartIndex1 = len(" ".join(i[0:y]))+1
                wordEndIndex1 = len(" ".join(i[0:y]))+ len(word)+1
                list_json[x]["labels"].append([wordStartIndex1, wordEndIndex1, j])
```

You get the format below:
`list_json[0:2]`
output:
```
[{'id': 0,
  'text': 'EU rejects German call to boycott British lamb .',
  'labels': [[0, 2, 'B-ORG'], [11, 17, 'B-MISC'], [34, 41, 'B-MISC']]},
 {'id': 1,
  'text': 'Peter Blackburn',
  'labels': [[0, 5, 'B-PER'], [6, 15, 'I-PER']]}]
```

Which you can then convert using the code below:

```
from itertools import groupby
new_labels = []

for y, i in enumerate(list_json):
    # creating an empty sublist to append to the list of lists
    merged_labels = []
    
    # creating a list by combining the start character of every label, such as "BIBBI"
    label_names = [item[2] for item in i["labels"]]
    label_BIO = [item[0] for item in label_names]
    L = list(label_BIO)
    
    # This for loop applies if there is only 1 tag to the whole where the label_BIO is only "B"
    
    for single_b_tag in range(len(L)):
        # if there is no "I" after a "B" tag, it just appends the single word
        if (i["labels"][single_b_tag][2][0] == "B") and (len(L)==1):
            merged_labels.append([i["labels"][single_b_tag][0], # append the start index
                                  i["labels"][single_b_tag][1], # append the end index
                                  i["labels"][single_b_tag][2][2:]]) # append the original label with "B-" in front
    
    # this for loop is for the ones where there are multiple "B" tags but no "I tags"
    for x in range(len(L)-1):
        # if there is a B tag that is not followed by an I tag
        if i["labels"][x][2][0] == "B" and i["labels"][x+1][2][0] != "I":
            merged_labels.append([i["labels"][x][0], 
                                  i["labels"][x][1], 
                                  i["labels"][x][2][2:]])
        
        # if the last element in label key is B and there is no other tag after it, (if enumerated x is the same as the length)
        # then append it as it is, without the "B-" in front
        if (i["labels"][x+1][2][0] == "B") and (x+1 == len(L)-1):
            merged_labels.append([i["labels"][x+1][0], 
                                  i["labels"][x+1][1], 
                                  i["labels"][x+1][2][2:]])
    
    # Creates a list of tuples where each consecutive duplicates are detected such as: [('B', 1), ('I', 1), ('B', 2), ('I', 1)]
    grouped_L = [(k, sum(1 for i in g)) for k,g in groupby(L)]
    num_of_seq = int(len(grouped_L)) # the number of sequences is where "I" is detected after "B" is normally this number divided by 2
                                     # but instead of dividing by 2, I decided to count uneven numbers so the iteration goes for as many items there is a sequence
    
    for seq_iter in range(num_of_seq):
        if seq_iter % 2 == 1:
            # Every second element in the tuple list is an "I" tag followed by a "B" tag, this iterations applies num_of_seq/2 times 
            # (I found this is better instead of dividing num_of_seq by 2)
            # So for every sequence it detects the beginning of the sequence and the end of the sequence
            
            seq_length = grouped_L[seq_iter][1] + 1 # second element of the tuple is how many times the "I" is repeated
                                                    # adding 1 because there is a "B" before so the total is "I"*n+"B"
            first_index_of_seq = [i[1] for i in grouped_L[0:seq_iter]] # count how many words have been used until the nth sequence
            first_index_of_seq = sum(first_index_of_seq)-1 # -1 because indexing starts at 0
            last_index_of_seq = [i[1] for i in grouped_L[0:seq_iter+1]]
            last_index_of_seq = sum(last_index_of_seq)-1 # -1 because indexing starts at 0
            
            merged_labels.append([i["labels"][first_index_of_seq][0],i["labels"][last_index_of_seq][1],i["labels"][last_index_of_seq][2][2:]])
            
    new_labels.append(merged_labels)
```

Which gives:
`new_labels[0:2]`
output:
```
[[[0, 2, 'ORG'], [11, 17, 'MISC'], [34, 41, 'MISC']], 
[[0, 15, 'PER']]]
```

And then just replace the json_list, "label" key with the new list:
````
# replace the old label list with the new one
for i in range(len(list_json)):
    list_json[i]["labels"] = new_labels[i]
````

`list_json[0:2]`
output:
```
[{'id': 0,
  'text': 'EU rejects German call to boycott British lamb .',
  'labels': [[0, 2, 'ORG'], [11, 17, 'MISC'], [34, 41, 'MISC']]},
 {'id': 1,
  'text': 'Peter Blackburn', 
  'labels': [[0, 15, 'PER']]}]
```

Then you can just save the list of dicts as a json1 file

```
# you can just dump a list of dictionaries as a json1 file
# which is the format required by doccano
import json
with open('justtryin.json1', 'w') as f:
    for d in list_json[0:200]:
        json.dump(d, f)
        f.write('\n')
```

Then just upload this json file to the site. I looked around 200 sentences and detected no problems so far. Although I also did try uploading my poorly trained model outputs to cut back on time required to label, but found that if the ConLL format is wrong this code works poorly. For instance if you have a label starting with B, and then no labels("O") for 3 words, and then a random label starting with "I", 5 labels become tagged as one, since the "I" label originally had no "B" tag associated with it.

@icoxfog417 @Hironsan If you think this is helpful, feel free to use this on your platform. You can change and modify whatever you want. You can probably make this a lot more efficient. I have only recently started programming so I have zero clue about code efficiency. But this method works and that's really what matters for me. Also if there is a problem with the code, let me know so I can fix wherever there is a mistake.

Note: I originaly tried this with private data where I had 12 total labels. It works the same with however many labels you may have.

If anyone needs the code to transform ConLL 2003 format to a list of lists which I used above, feel free to @ me. I can also share that if anyone needs it. But you can find it online very easily.

issue.title: Improve upload and download features

repository.name: doccano
repository.description: Open source annotation tool for machine learning practitioners.

issue.body:
## Upload

- [x] Support a large file upload
- [x] Support a folder upload
- [x] Support multiple files upload
- [x] Support asynchronous upload
- [x] Enable to show upload progress

## Ingestion

- [x] Support batch import to speed up the process
- [x] Support file validation
- [x] Import as much of the file's content as possible
- [x] Provide feedback on which file and what line is wrong and why.
- [x] Support 90 over encodings
- [x] Support auto encoding detection
- [x] Support saving filename

## File format

- [x] Expand the available formats
- [x] Support for specifying columns for labels and text
- [x] Support for specifying schema of CoNLL(IOB2, IOE2, IOBES, BILOU)
- [x] Support for specifying separator(CSV, CoNLL)

## Download

- [x] Support a large file download
- [x] Support asynchronous download
- [x] Support zip download
- [x] Support JSON download

## Related issues

fix #1299
fix #1292 
fix #1291 
fix #1286 
fix #1267
fix #1265
